text: The Science Club wants to promote environmental awareness in the community. It organizes a campaign to have families build and use 1-2-3 compost boxes.

Recipe for a 1-2-3 Compost Box

A 1-2-3 box will decompose about 0.5 pound of garbage a day.

  • Start with an open rectangular wood box that is 1 foot high, 2 feet wide, and 3 feet long. This is a 1-2-3 box.
  • Mix 10 pounds of shredded newspaper with 15 quarts of water. Put the mixture in the 1-2-3 box.
  • Add a few handfuls of soil.
  • Add about 1,000 redworms (about 1 pound).

Every day, mix 0.5 pounds of kitchen waste with the soil in the box. The worms will do the rest of the work. They will turn the waste into new soil.

Suppose families want to double the amount of garbage they compost.

  • What are the possible dimensions of the new box? Make or build a sketch of the 1-2-3 box and the new box to support your reasoning.

Note: Many students intuitively think to double all of the dimensions. There is often surprise when this leads to 8 times the volume. This is nicely demonstrated with “boxes” made from grid paper.

Students can make quick discoveries with a box built from grid paper.

A 1-2-3 box can contain 6 unit cubes. When you double the amount of 1-2-3 box, then you will have 12 unit cubes. In other words, if you double 1-2-3 box, it will be the same amount of 2 boxes. You can stack two boxes in three different ways: along the height, along the length, along the width.
• How many worms would you need? Explain your reasoning.
1 pound. You need twice many worms of 1-2-3 box.
• Is the box you sketched similar to the 1-2-3 box? Explain.

No. When you want to double the volume, you will double only one dimension of three (the length, the width, or the height). To make them similar, on the other hand, you need to double all of the length, the width, and the height.
• Suppose you want to triple the amount of garbage they compost. What are the dimensions of the new box?
